{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-29697].
  {panel}

The page properties macro is only able to retrieve property values from its own body text if the properties are contained within a HTML table element that declares a TBODY element containing its rows.

According to the HTML 5 spec, the TBODY element may be omitted from a table declaration if the table contains only TR elements and no table header and footer. (http://www.w3.org/TR/html-markup/tbody.html#tbody-tags)

This means that if another macro embedded within the page properties macro produces table output, even if the output of the macro is well-formed and valid HTML or Confluence Storage Format, the properties may not always be picked up.

This is the case for Bob Swift's SQL Query macro, which generates table output that omits the TBODY element declaration.
fields.summary: Page Properties macro cannot determine properties from a well-formed table generated by a child macro

ID: CONF-001 - Information Exposure
CWE ID: 200
CWE Description: An information exposure is the intentional or unintentional disclosure of information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.
Additional description: One REST service (/rest/likes/1.0/content) doesn't (properly) authenticate requests. An anonymous user can request a list of 'likes' from arbitrary pages that aren't accessible for anonymous users. Confluence returns a list of Confluence usernames as well as full usernames that 'like' that page.
This could help an attacker: By bruteforcing page_ID it's possible to obtain a list of usernames and full usernames of all persons that have 'liked' one or more pages.
Affected URL(s):
/rest/likes/1.0/content/<page_ID>/likes
/rest/likes/1.0/content/<page_ID>/comment-likes
fields.summary: /rest/likes/1.0/content does not check page permissions properly

  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-29664].
  {panel}

Hello, We have noticed that Confluence adds a prefix to anchor names, which is really odd.
When I add an anchor macro to a page, with name lets say 'prices' the anchor is renamed to 'pagename-prices' and a link like 'confluenceinstalation/wiki/display/pagename#prices' <- doesn't work. 
We have to use the prefixed anchor which would be 'confluenceinstalation/wiki/display/pagename#pagename-prices. Why the redundant page name? 
This means the anchor will change the name with the page. If I use a link like the above it's not a big inconvenience , but all short links will be invalid, and also links of type 'viewpage.action?pageId=12313#pagename-prices' will become invalid if the 'pagename' is changed to lets say 'changedname'. Now the links would be 'viewpage.action?pageId=12313#changedname-prices' also short links will change like '/xTxY/WszA#changedname-prices'. If the anchor was not prefixed all those links would still be valid. I am also talking about the heading anchors that are generated automatically. 

Can this be made configurable, so that we can choose if Confluence should add prefix to the anchor name or no prefix at all?
fields.summary: Page name prefix in anchors

  {panel}

We should document the Confluence.Binder components.

This will be particularly useful for plugin developers who write forms on pages. 

*Background:* 

In Confluence 5.2, we introduced a nice new feature for developers: "Multi-user selection fields". This is not very useful for developers who want to be able to use it in the macro browser. They would have to get into the complexity of {{setMacroJsOverride}}.

But not all plugin developers live in the macro browser. Sometimes they write forms on pages too. For example, a plugin that asks people to enter comma-separated usernames. Adding a class to the field would greatly improve the UX.

We currently don't have any public documentation on the Confluence.Binder components, and for that reason we didn't document the new "Multi-user selection fields" feature either.
fields.summary: Developer docs: Document the Confluence.Binder components

Whenever I create a link in an email or external site that points to a Wiki page I use this format.

    Wiki : "Title of page" (http://wiki.mycompany.com/x/tinylink)

Now I have sufficient self-discipline to keep this up, but most of my colleagues keep on making a mess. Just putting in the address bar URL or only the tiny link. My reason for doing it like this is that it is more descriptive than just a tiny link. And in case that it does break users have a title and the name Wiki to go and search.

My request would be to have this as a complete formatted string available in the "Link to this page" popup that you get when pressing the "k" in view mode. Possibly by making the mask configurable per space.

A plugin or macro that would give me the same effect would be good too. But I prefer it to be in the standard product. Seems like an easy win even.

Regards,
Peter

Hi team, would it be feasible to move the gallery's horizontal scroll bar to the top of the gallery?

We've discovered that when employees use the Gallery macro and they have the sidebar expanded, they only see three out of the default four columns of the gallery macro. Often, due to the way that the gallery shows three columns almost perfectly in the default theme, it's not clear that there is a fourth column at all, unless one scrolls down the entire gallery and notices the horizontal scroll bar at the bottom. As a result, employees sometimes miss an entire column of images.

Would it be feasible to move the scroll bar to the top of the gallery when there are too many columns to display onscreen? This would be a quick and easy visual indicator that the employee will need to scroll to see the full gallery.

Thanks for considering it,
Joe
fields.summary: request to move the gallery scroll bar to the top of the gallery

I am currently writing a plug-in which shares pages by parsing incoming e-mail (https://github.com/schakko/Confluence-Mail-to-News-Plugin). The plug-in is realized as a trigger so there is no HttpServletContext available.

For the plug-in I use the SharePageImpl.sharePage() method but the call results in a NullPointerException: createWebResourceDataSource() access the ServletContextThreadLocal which is not available. 
To solve this issue I have to use the deprecated API method ServletContextThreadLocal.setRequest(new MockHttpServletRequest()) with a mocked/stubbed instance of HttpServletRequest (https://github.com/schakko/Confluence-Mail-to-News-Plugin/blob/master/src/main/java/com/midori/confluence/plugin/mail2news/MailToBlogPostPublisher.java#L109).

Please provide a method which initializes the ServletContextThreadLocal if a non-servlet plug-in runs or remove the @deprecated tag from ServletContextThreadLocal.setRequest().
fields.summary: API: Please provide a method to initialize the ServletContextThreadLocal from a trigger plug-in

  {panel}

Our very early versions of Blueprints enforced structure.

For example, no matter where you were in the space, if you said Add > Meeting, it _always_ went under the meeting notes index page.

We had a bit of feedback about this from customers who typically had the "multiple projects per space" use case that this was frustrating. As an example, they would want a "file list" for every project. So they always had to move the page they created to under the appropriate project page. 

We feel that the primary problem here stems from the fact that Blueprints can only have one index page per space. If we had the ability to create multiple index pages per space, we could always enforce that blueprints are created under their index page and enforce this structure.
fields.summary: Enforce all blueprints to be placed under their index page / support multiple index pages per space

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-29482].
  {panel}

h3. Background of Request

The current behavior of Confluence is to hide both child pages list in the lower part of the page and child page tree in the side navigation bar of "Documentation Theme".

This behavior require user to click at least once to see the list of child pages  of the parent page accessed and due to the design of the new drop down button it is hard to differentiate pages that have children and the one that doesn't have child pages. Since opening up the whole child page list in the lower part of the page could be aesthetically unpleasing if the number of child pages is huge, we should provide the option for this at side bar navigation. 

h3. Proposed Solution

Since "Documentation Theme" provide side  navigation bar to, it would be great if administrator or users of Confluence has the ability to configure it to open the child page tree automatically when the parent page accessed.

Hence user will be able to use side navigation bar to see the list of child pages without clicking it.

For administrator, this configuration should be provided at theme configuration. For users, this configuration should be provided at user profile preferences option.

Another method is to improve the button icon to be a bigger and higher contrast so user would at least able to differentiate it easily.
fields.summary: Expand Child Pages Tree Automatically When Opening Parent Page

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Cloud*. Using *Confluence Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFSERVER-29478].
  {panel}

h3. Background of Request

As of now, Confluence what's new feature can only be configurable to point to another Confluence page or link through modifying {{help.prefix}} as describe here:

* [Configuring the What's New Dialog|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Configuring+the+What's+New+Dialog]

However, help prefix also necessary when customer want to localized their help section as describe [here|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Local+Confluence+Documentation#LocalConfluenceDocumentation-helppagelinks]. This made the current method of What's New configuration unusable if customer want to use its own locale but keep the what's new to Atlassian site as describe [here|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONF-29065].

h3. Proposed Solution

It would be great if Confluence provide a user interface method for What's new feature that cover the following option:

* Follow {{help.prefix}}, and provide the field to input the prefix
* Follow Atlassian site. This means it will always follow Atlassian What's new link repository which check against its version
* Full Path URL. This provide the option to point to a specific URL
fields.summary: User Interface Configuration for What's New
